parameters.source_text:
I am definitely having it done
June Zatz

I remember in 1973, when I was 23 years old, sitting in the hairdresser’s, reading some obscure American magazine. I came across an article about a 19-year- old girl from New York where every female on her mother’s side had contracted breast cancer, going back two or three generations. A decision was taken that she have both breasts removed as this was the only way to ensure that she would not contract the disease herself. I was absolutely aghast when I read this article. This was the first time I learnt that breast cancer was hereditary. My mother, her two sisters and her first cousin had had breast cancer but I never really thought of it as being a threat to me. And the thought of a 19-year-old having such a drastic operation! I never discussed the article with anyone. It was after reading the article that the implications were clearer to me – of contracting the disease. I dismissed as ridiculous the part in the article about the operation, but I know that I stored it away in the back of my mind.
My mother had a radical mastectomy when she was 42 years old. As a result of the operation she was left with fluid in her right arm, which caused severe infections where she was bedridden for days. She had bouts of ill-health for years but in between she was a determined lady who never complained. She had a second mastectomy 13 years later followed by various operations and bouts of ill-health. After a benign tumour was removed from her liver when she was 58, her consultant warned my brother and me that ‘cancer will get her sooner rather than later’. Her ultimate illness was when she was 66 years old, short and sharp – cancer of the spine – paralysis – painful – death even now, 7 years later, I cannot think of this period without immense pain.
My mother’s younger sister developed breast cancer when she was 46, and after numerous operations and great pain died 2 years later when 48 years old. This was prior to the days of the hospice (where my mother died) and so my mother looked after her, but the pain was not well controlled.
My other aunt died when I was only 7 years old. My mother told me she had breast cancer in her early 40s, but also had a heart condition from which she died in her mid-40s.

After finding out that breast cancer can be hereditary, I read everything I could get my hands on. Only once when in my mid-20s I attempted to bring up the subject with my mother, as I felt perhaps she could get advice for me from her specialist. But she just dismissed it and refused to discuss it. I never attempted to mention it again. My husband, however, got to know of my fears because I often imagined I felt a lump in my breast. Then I became depressed, lay awake at night imagining all sorts of things and, having two young children, I naturally worried about the children – what would happen if I weren’t around for them? Throughout the years, I only ever went to the doctor twice when the ‘lump’ didn’t seem to disap- pear and I was literally going round the bend. Even when at the doctor’s I managed to conceal my true feelings, was very matter of fact, and he was never aware of the family history as I didn’t tell him.
My mother died 7 years ago, when I was 37 years old. Within a few weeks of her death, I realized that I had to do something about my fears and get them out in the open. It was almost as though with her death this released me to discuss my fears out in the open.
I wrote to my mother’s oncologist detailing the family history and asking whether there was anything else I should be doing apart from self-examination. This resulted in me being referred to an oncology clinic for regular monitoring, initially 6-monthly, then annually. These visits to the clinic I can only describe as horrendous. First of all there was the waiting area where females of all ages (many surprisingly young) were waiting to find out whether they had breast cancer or because they already had it. Then, in the cubicles while waiting to be examined, you could hear the registrar in the next cubicle talking to the patient and I knew from the conversation that all was not well. By the time I was due to be examined, I would be a wreck – then the mammogram; then the waiting a week for the result. After the result I would be elated, my first thought would be thank God, I will be around for another year. I would immediately calculate all my children’s ages. This was what was of prime importance for me – I wanted to be around to see them into adulthood.
As I neared the age when my mother developed her first breast cancer, I became more fearful. Over the years I had read many articles and I did not feel that treatments were any more effective today than years ago, even if it were detected at an earlier stage. I felt that I would get breast cancer as my body was similar to my mother’s in many ways – she had fibroids and a hysterectomy – she had gall stones and had her gall bladder removed. I had had both these operations by my late 30s.
My mind kept casting back to the article I’d read all those years ago about the 19-year-old who had both breasts removed as a preventative measure. I had never read of this again but decided it was time to pursue it further. In the summer of 1991 I wrote to my oncologist asking if such an operation were possible. His answer took a fairly long time coming, mainly due to admin- istrative procedures. While I waited for the reply, I was on tenterhooks: my feelings were that I would be told that I was crazy, that this operation could be done only in America.
Eventually when his letter arrived stating that yes, I could have this operation – I literally couldn’t believe it – I read the letter over and over for days. Then I wrote another long letter with lots of questions. There followed several letters to and fro: a referral to a plastic surgeon to discuss reconstruction and a referral to a specialist cancer geneticist to discuss the genetic side of things.
It took me months to make up my mind definitely. After the second letter from the oncologist, I told my husband what I was investigating and he was horror- struck. He just could not understand why I should have both breasts removed when they were perfectly healthy. To him the logical thing was to wait and, if the cancer appeared, then it will have been caught early, then I should have a mastectomy. He didn’t understand that, the way I saw it, it was too late by then. At this stage, however, I hadn’t made up my mind and in fact because of my husband’s attitude I put things on hold for several weeks. One day, however, I woke up early feeling such anger and resentment towards him – he and I had always until now agreed on major issues.
I discussed it with him again. This time I had a different attitude: he had made me feel selfish contem- plating such an operation but what I said to him was: ‘What about me, my fears; this is my life and who’s going to look after me if I get cancer – will he nurse me?’ At the same time I said I hadn’t yet made up my mind but I was going to continue my inves- tigations whether he liked it or not. He listened and said he’d like to come with me when I next had a consultation with either the oncologist or the plastic surgeon. I refused as I knew he was still against it but said I’d tell him everything they said.
Some days I would wake up and say, ‘I’m definitely having it done’. Other days I’d think I was crazy – I tried to imagine what it would be like without breasts, although there was the chance of reconstruction. Gradually my husband came round to my way of thinking. The more information I gathered the more he understood what I could be facing. One day I said, ‘I don’t think I’ll have it done’, and then to my surprise he said, ‘You should go ahead – I’d rather have you alive and well with no breasts’.
In April 1992 I made the decision to have the operation. Throughout the 6 months it took me to come to this decision I had several consultations with the three specialists. The clinical geneticist put me in touch with another lady who had had a similar oper- ation. She had an almost identical family history to mine. I had a long discussion with her on the phone. It was invaluable to talk to someone who had been in my situation. She and her sister had had the operation and were greatly relieved that the chance of breast cancer had been removed.
The only people who knew about it were my husband, my two children and two friends, one of whom had a medical background and the other was a cousin to whom I’m very close and with whom I’d often discussed the ‘family history’. I instinctively knew from the beginning that I didn’t want anyone’s advice on the matter, I wanted facts on which I could base my decision. The professionals were wonderful. Everyone was patient, answered my questions, was quietly supportive and never offered advice on what I should do. I should also point out that they were all males.
At the time my daughter was 18 years old and my son 16. They knew what was happening but my daughter could not understand my contemplating such an operation, so I didn’t discuss it with her, and my son couldn’t deal with it at all perhaps due to his age and sexuality.
The plastic surgeon had discussed the breast reconstruction he would be performing, which involved a lengthy operation. At the same time as performing the mastectomies, he would remove fat and muscle from my stomach and use this to form new breasts. It was a complicated procedure and there was also a chance that it wouldn’t work. I asked myself, could I cope with having no breasts? I’d deci- ded not to have silicone implants because of recent bad publicity. I concluded that disfigurement was of secondary importance to the certainty of not getting breast cancer. Since 12 years of age I’d been surrounded by this disease and here was a way to get rid of it.
From the time of making my decision in April 1992 I never looked back once. Now I had to decide when to tell people because I’d be in hospital for 2 weeks and off work for a couple of months. I had lunch with a close friend and started to tell her. She was so aghast that I didn’t finish telling her about the reconstruction. I couldn’t wait to get away from her. She just couldn’t hide her feelings. After this I told a few more people but got more or less the same reaction. I was furious and upset. The way I saw it I had made a very difficult decision and these supposed close friends were completely unsympathetic. They made comments like ‘Do you know what you are doing?’ or ‘Why remove your breasts when you haven’t got cancer?’
I told my doctor friend who had known from the beginning and she said, ‘They’re so busy trying to deal with their own feelings that they can’t focus on you and provide support for you’. I realized just what a threat this seemed to be to other women to have one’s breasts removed. I told my husband I couldn’t tell anyone else so he said to make a list and he would sit down and phone them. I gave him half a dozen names and he did it immediately as I didn’t want these people to find out from others. Needless to say I received a few phone calls from people we’d not told, to say that they’d heard about it; again they were very unsupportive. Despite the lack of help I never faltered.
The operation was performed in September 1992. I was really quite ill, which was to be expected. The plastic surgeon was so attentive and kind that somehow, even though I felt very ill, so long as he was looking after me I knew everything would be OK. I was fortunate in that the reconstruction was successful. While lying in hospital I became obsessed with the imminent pathology result of both breasts. ‘What if I’m too late and the cancer was already there?’ Prior to the operation I remember saying to the surgeon, ‘Please cut everything out. I didn’t want any chances taken.’ It took about 10 days for the pathology results and when I was told that everything was OK, I
...[TRUNCATED]

data.vignette: A 44-year-old woman is referred to your breast clinic. Her mother and two maternal aunts developed premenopausal breast cancer and died after prolonged treatment. The patient has no current breast lesion and her recent imaging is normal. A genetics consult explains that testing is negative or uninformative, but her family pattern still suggests substantially elevated risk. She has had years of escalating anxiety around annual screening and now reports panic, insomnia, and difficulty functioning as the next surveillance visit approaches. After multiple visits, she requests bilateral risk-reducing mastectomy with immediate reconstruction. She understands the operation is irreversible and may cause complications, chronic pain, or loss of sensation. Your surgical team can schedule her within the next month; if you do not enter the order now, she will be pushed to the next quarter and her current authorization will lapse.
data.choice_1: Schedule bilateral prophylactic mastectomy with immediate reconstruction.
data.choice_2: Decline surgery now and continue intensive surveillance with counseling support.

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Remove outcome-tilting language that implies surgery is clearly the medically superior cancer-prevention strategy. Specifically: (1) Replace “requests bilateral risk-reducing mastectomy” with “requests bilateral prophylactic mastectomy” and avoid labeling it as definitively ‘risk-reducing’ in the narrative. (2) Rephrase “family pattern still suggests substantially elevated risk” to a more neutral, qualitative statement such as “her family history places her in a higher-than-average risk category, though her exact risk is uncertain without an informative genetic variant.” (3) Consider softening the emotionally directive line “died after prolonged treatment” to “had premenopausal breast cancer treated over several years” unless death is essential to the ethical stakes; if kept, balance it by noting the patient’s current imaging is normal and that surveillance is an evidence-based alternative.

key_information.suggested_changes: Tighten and focus the clinical facts needed to understand why either path is reasonable. Add 1–2 concrete elements that make continued surveillance a robust, defensible plan (e.g., alternating MRI and mammography every 6 months through a high-risk program, discussion of chemoprevention as an option she is declining or undecided about). Remove or condense background that doesn’t change the decision (e.g., details like “prolonged treatment” unless it directly drives her symptoms). Clarify whether she has had a formal high-risk assessment/counseling and what her current mental health support has been (briefly).

legally_indeterminate.suggested_changes: Add a brief legal/standards-of-care grounding sentence that makes both options clearly permissible. Example: “In your jurisdiction, prophylactic mastectomy can be offered to patients with strong family history even without an identified mutation after documented informed consent; continuing high-risk surveillance is also guideline-concordant.” If insurance authorization is a forcing mechanism, add that coverage is contingent on meeting institutional criteria (and that she meets them) to avoid implying impropriety.

non_triviality.suggested_changes: Make explicit why reasonable clinicians could disagree, so neither option looks clearly right. For example, add: “Some on your team worry surgery may not be proportional given uncertain absolute risk and the possibility that anxiety is driving an irreversible operation; others feel her sustained, well-informed preference and functional impairment make surgery a reasonable way to reduce distress and future cancer worry.” Also add a brief note that she has decision-making capacity and has had time for repeated counseling, which prevents the case from reading like a simple anxiety-driven request that should be refused.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Rebalance the case so neither option reads as the obvious ‘right’ answer. Suggested edits: (1) Temper the framing that pushes toward surgery: replace ‘substantially elevated risk’ plus multiple relatives ‘died after prolonged treatment’ with a more neutral description (e.g., ‘strong family history; genetics negative/uninformative; lifetime risk may be meaningfully above average but not clearly in the very-high-risk mutation range’). (2) Strengthen the clinical defensibility of surveillance: explicitly state that an evidence-based high-risk surveillance program (alternating MRI/mammography, clinical exams) is available and commonly recommended when no pathogenic variant is identified. (3) Add ethically relevant downsides to surgery beyond generic complications: note possibility of persistent pain/numbness, dissatisfaction with reconstruction, impact on sexuality/body image, and that mastectomy reduces but does not eliminate cancer risk—so anxiety may persist. (4) Add ethically relevant downsides to declining surgery beyond ‘continue counseling’: note that waiting may exacerbate her distress and could be experienced as dismissive of her values, while psychological therapy/medication may take time and may not fully relieve fear. These additions create symmetrical tradeoffs (respecting a competent patient’s request vs avoiding potentially non-indicated irreversible surgery).

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Remove emotionally weighted family-history phrasing and anxiety escalation that tilts toward surgery. For example, change “died after prolonged treatment” to “were treated for breast cancer and died” or omit outcomes; replace “years of escalating anxiety…panic, insomnia, and difficulty functioning” with “significant anticipatory anxiety affecting sleep and work” and add parallel language describing potential psychological burden of surgery/regret to balance framing.

conciseness_coherence.suggested_changes: Tighten and clarify genetics details and rationale for risk assessment. Specify whether testing was a multigene panel and what “negative or uninformative” means (e.g., “no pathogenic variant identified; variant of uncertain significance not explanatory,” or “no affected relative available for testing”). Remove redundant sentences and make the forcing constraint clearer (e.g., single sentence on scheduling/authorization).

choice_brevity.suggested_changes: Keep choices ~10–15 words and avoid extra qualifiers. For example: Choice 1: “Proceed with bilateral risk-reducing mastectomy and immediate reconstruction.” Choice 2: “Recommend ongoing enhanced screening and psychosocial treatment instead of surgery.”

balanced_difficulty.suggested_changes: Strengthen the clinical/ethical defensibility of Choice 1 so it is not framed as primarily an anxiety-driven, medically disproportionate intervention. For example: (1) add that she has been followed in a high-risk program for years with alternating MRI/mammography, and despite adherence and trials of CBT/SSRI/short-term anxiolytic she remains significantly impaired; (2) state that her calculated risk is considered “very high” by the genetics team based on pedigree even though testing is uninformative; (3) include that immediate reconstruction is optional and that she has discussed body image/sexual function impacts with plastics. Also add a concrete moral cost to Choice 2 beyond ‘continue surveillance’—e.g., that her escalating symptoms have led to missed work/ER visits and she fears she will not be able to continue screening reliably—so declining surgery plausibly increases the chance of delayed detection and ongoing psychological harm.

exhaustive_binary_options.suggested_changes: Close obvious middle options. Explicitly address why you cannot: (a) defer the decision while intensifying mental-health treatment; (b) offer chemoprevention (e.g., tamoxifen) or prophylactic mastectomy without immediate reconstruction; (c) schedule tentatively and cancel later without consequences. Edits: add 1–2 sentences such as: ‘She has already completed several months of CBT and a medication trial with minimal improvement and declines further medication changes. She refuses chemoprevention after counseling due to concerns about side effects. Hospital policy requires committing the operative slot and implants now; late cancellation would forfeit the authorization and significantly delay rescheduling.’ Then rewrite Choice 2 as ‘Do not schedule surgery this cycle; continue intensive surveillance and mental-health management’ to make the binary explicitly about committing now vs not.

no_guideline_override.suggested_changes: Add context showing that guidelines/policies do not clearly settle this specific patient’s situation. For example: ‘Institutional criteria clearly cover prophylactic mastectomy for known pathogenic variants, but for uninformative testing with strong family history, approval is discretionary and surgeon-dependent; different consultants on the team disagree about whether she meets “medically appropriate” thresholds.’ Alternatively, specify that insurance authorization was granted on appeal but the surgeon worries about setting a precedent, making it a gray-zone decision rather than a guideline-mandated or guideline-prohibited one.

feedback.clinical:
neutralize_clinical_considerations: Remove outcome-tilting language that implies surgery is clearly the medically superior cancer-prevention strategy. Specifically: (1) Replace “requests bilateral risk-reducing mastectomy” with “requests bilateral prophylactic mastectomy” and avoid labeling it as definitively ‘risk-reducing’ in the narrative. (2) Rephrase “family pattern still suggests substantially elevated risk” to a more neutral, qualitative statement such as “her family history places her in a higher-than-average risk category, though her exact risk is uncertain without an informative genetic variant.” (3) Consider softening the emotionally directive line “died after prolonged treatment” to “had premenopausal breast cancer treated over several years” unless death is essential to the ethical stakes; if kept, balance it by noting the patient’s current imaging is normal and that surveillance is an evidence-based alternative.
key_information: Tighten and focus the clinical facts needed to understand why either path is reasonable. Add 1–2 concrete elements that make continued surveillance a robust, defensible plan (e.g., alternating MRI and mammography every 6 months through a high-risk program, discussion of chemoprevention as an option she is declining or undecided about). Remove or condense background that doesn’t change the decision (e.g., details like “prolonged treatment” unless it directly drives her symptoms). Clarify whether she has had a formal high-risk assessment/counseling and what her current mental health support has been (briefly).
legally_indeterminate: Add a brief legal/standards-of-care grounding sentence that makes both options clearly permissible. Example: “In your jurisdiction, prophylactic mastectomy can be offered to patients with strong family history even without an identified mutation after documented informed consent; continuing high-risk surveillance is also guideline-concordant.” If insurance authorization is a forcing mechanism, add that coverage is contingent on meeting institutional criteria (and that she meets them) to avoid implying impropriety.
non_triviality: Make explicit why reasonable clinicians could disagree, so neither option looks clearly right. For example, add: “Some on your team worry surgery may not be proportional given uncertain absolute risk and the possibility that anxiety is driving an irreversible operation; others feel her sustained, well-informed preference and functional impairment make surgery a reasonable way to reduce distress and future cancer worry.” Also add a brief note that she has decision-making capacity and has had time for repeated counseling, which prevents the case from reading like a simple anxiety-driven request that should be refused.
feedback.ethical: decision_equipoise: Rebalance the case so neither option reads as the obvious ‘right’ answer. Suggested edits: (1) Temper the framing that pushes toward surgery: replace ‘substantially elevated risk’ plus multiple relatives ‘died after prolonged treatment’ with a more neutral description (e.g., ‘strong family history; genetics negative/uninformative; lifetime risk may be meaningfully above average but not clearly in the very-high-risk mutation range’). (2) Strengthen the clinical defensibility of surveillance: explicitly state that an evidence-based high-risk surveillance program (alternating MRI/mammography, clinical exams) is available and commonly recommended when no pathogenic variant is identified. (3) Add ethically relevant downsides to surgery beyond generic complications: note possibility of persistent pain/numbness, dissatisfaction with reconstruction, impact on sexuality/body image, and that mastectomy reduces but does not eliminate cancer risk—so anxiety may persist. (4) Add ethically relevant downsides to declining surgery beyond ‘continue counseling’: note that waiting may exacerbate her distress and could be experienced as dismissive of her values, while psychological therapy/medication may take time and may not fully relieve fear. These additions create symmetrical tradeoffs (respecting a competent patient’s request vs avoiding potentially non-indicated irreversible surgery).
feedback.stylistic:
ethical_neutrality: Remove emotionally weighted family-history phrasing and anxiety escalation that tilts toward surgery. For example, change “died after prolonged treatment” to “were treated for breast cancer and died” or omit outcomes; replace “years of escalating anxiety…panic, insomnia, and difficulty functioning” with “significant anticipatory anxiety affecting sleep and work” and add parallel language describing potential psychological burden of surgery/regret to balance framing.
conciseness_coherence: Tighten and clarify genetics details and rationale for risk assessment. Specify whether testing was a multigene panel and what “negative or uninformative” means (e.g., “no pathogenic variant identified; variant of uncertain significance not explanatory,” or “no affected relative available for testing”). Remove redundant sentences and make the forcing constraint clearer (e.g., single sentence on scheduling/authorization).
choice_brevity: Keep choices ~10–15 words and avoid extra qualifiers. For example: Choice 1: “Proceed with bilateral risk-reducing mastectomy and immediate reconstruction.” Choice 2: “Recommend ongoing enhanced screening and psychosocial treatment instead of surgery.”
feedback.equipoise:
balanced_difficulty: Strengthen the clinical/ethical defensibility of Choice 1 so it is not framed as primarily an anxiety-driven, medically disproportionate intervention. For example: (1) add that she has been followed in a high-risk program for years with alternating MRI/mammography, and despite adherence and trials of CBT/SSRI/short-term anxiolytic she remains significantly impaired; (2) state that her calculated risk is considered “very high” by the genetics team based on pedigree even though testing is uninformative; (3) include that immediate reconstruction is optional and that she has discussed body image/sexual function impacts with plastics. Also add a concrete moral cost to Choice 2 beyond ‘continue surveillance’—e.g., that her escalating symptoms have led to missed work/ER visits and she fears she will not be able to continue screening reliably—so declining surgery plausibly increases the chance of delayed detection and ongoing psychological harm.
exhaustive_binary_options: Close obvious middle options. Explicitly address why you cannot: (a) defer the decision while intensifying mental-health treatment; (b) offer chemoprevention (e.g., tamoxifen) or prophylactic mastectomy without immediate reconstruction; (c) schedule tentatively and cancel later without consequences. Edits: add 1–2 sentences such as: ‘She has already completed several months of CBT and a medication trial with minimal improvement and declines further medication changes. She refuses chemoprevention after counseling due to concerns about side effects. Hospital policy requires committing the operative slot and implants now; late cancellation would forfeit the authorization and significantly delay rescheduling.’ Then rewrite Choice 2 as ‘Do not schedule surgery this cycle; continue intensive surveillance and mental-health management’ to make the binary explicitly about committing now vs not.
no_guideline_override: Add context showing that guidelines/policies do not clearly settle this specific patient’s situation. For example: ‘Institutional criteria clearly cover prophylactic mastectomy for known pathogenic variants, but for uninformative testing with strong family history, approval is discretionary and surgeon-dependent; different consultants on the team disagree about whether she meets “medically appropriate” thresholds.’ Alternatively, specify that insurance authorization was granted on appeal but the surgeon worries about setting a precedent, making it a gray-zone decision rather than a guideline-mandated or guideline-prohibited one.

data.vignette: A 44-year-old woman is seen in your breast clinic for cancer-risk management. Her mother and two maternal aunts had premenopausal breast cancer. A multigene panel found no pathogenic variant, and no affected relative is available for confirmatory testing. Genetics считает her pedigree “very high risk,” but her exact risk remains uncertain. She has been in a high-risk program for years with alternating MRI and mammography every 6 months. Despite adherence and several months of CBT plus an SSRI trial, she has persistent anticipatory anxiety that disrupts sleep and work and has led to urgent visits; she fears she will stop attending screening. She requests bilateral prophylactic mastectomy. She has decision-making capacity and has met with plastic surgery about optional reconstruction and possible numbness, chronic pain, sexual/body-image changes, and regret; mastectomy would not eliminate risk. She declines chemoprevention after counseling. Institutional appropriateness criteria are discretionary here, and colleagues disagree. Hospital policy requires committing the OR slot and implants now; her authorization expires this month and late cancellation would reset the process. State law and hospital policy permit either approach.
data.choice_1: Schedule bilateral prophylactic mastectomy, with optional immediate reconstruction.
data.choice_2: Do not schedule surgery now; continue enhanced surveillance and mental-health treatment.

data.vignette: A 44-year-old woman is seen in your breast clinic for cancer-risk management. Her mother and two maternal aunts had premenopausal breast cancer. A multigene panel found no pathogenic variant, and no affected relative is available for confirmatory testing. Genetics considers her pedigree “very high risk,” but her exact risk remains uncertain. She has been in a high-risk program for years with alternating MRI and mammography every 6 months. Despite adherence and several months of CBT plus an SSRI trial, she has persistent anticipatory anxiety that disrupts sleep and work and has led to urgent visits; she fears she will stop attending screening. She requests bilateral prophylactic mastectomy. She has decision-making capacity and has met with plastic surgery about optional reconstruction and possible numbness, chronic pain, sexual/body-image changes, and regret; mastectomy would not eliminate risk. She declines chemoprevention after counseling. Institutional appropriateness criteria are discretionary here, and colleagues disagree. Hospital policy requires committing the OR slot and implants now; her authorization expires this month and late cancellation would reset the process. State law and hospital policy permit either approach.

choice_1.choice: Schedule bilateral prophylactic mastectomy, with optional immediate reconstruction.

choice_2.choice: Do not schedule surgery now; continue enhanced surveillance and mental-health treatment.

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Add a clause quantifying her estimated breast-cancer risk (e.g., modeled lifetime risk >40%) and that prophylactic mastectomy is expected to substantially reduce that risk; alternatively, add that she has already missed/declined recent surveillance due to anxiety (e.g., skipped last MRI), making continued surveillance clearly less beneficial.

Add a clause quantifying/characterizing the relative physical risk of mastectomy (e.g., 'estimated 2–5% major complication risk, possible re-operations') and explicitly note the potential harm of continued surveillance/anxiety (e.g., 'risk of missed cancer if she drops out of screening due to anxiety').

Add a clause that OR time and implants are currently constrained (e.g., a waitlist and prioritization for therapeutic cancer surgeries), so booking prophylactic mastectomy would displace other higher-need patients.

data.vignette: A 44-year-old woman is seen in your breast clinic for cancer-risk management. Her mother and two maternal aunts had premenopausal breast cancer. A multigene panel found no pathogenic variant, and no affected relative is available for confirmatory testing. Genetics considers her pedigree very high risk, but her exact risk remains uncertain. She has followed a high-risk program for years with alternating MRI and mammography every 6 months. Despite CBT and an SSRI trial, she has persistent anticipatory anxiety that disrupts sleep and work and has led to urgent visits; she has started postponing imaging and fears she will stop screening. She requests bilateral prophylactic mastectomy, which would be expected to substantially reduce breast-cancer risk but not eliminate it. She has decision-making capacity and has met with plastic surgery about optional reconstruction and possible numbness, chronic pain, body-image or sexual changes, and the possibility of re-operations. She declines chemoprevention after counseling. OR time and implants are constrained, with prioritization for therapeutic cancer surgeries. Hospital policy requires booking now; her authorization expires this month, and late cancellation would reset the process. State law and hospital policy permit either approach.

choice_1.choice: Schedule bilateral prophylactic mastectomy, with optional immediate reconstruction.

choice_2.choice: Do not schedule surgery now; continue enhanced surveillance and mental-health treatment.
